title: Implement 'ai-repo add' command
description:
## Description
Implement the `ai-repo add command <file>` and `ai-repo add skill <folder>` commands.

## Instructions
1. Create `cmd/add.go`:
   - Define cobra command for "add"
   - Add subcommands: "command" and "skill"
   - Usage: 
     - `ai-repo add command <pathToFile.md>`
     - `ai-repo add skill <pathToFolder>`
   - Flags (common to both):
     - `--force`: overwrite existing resource
   - Command logic for "add command":
     - Validate path is a file ending in .md
     - Read and validate frontmatter
     - Derive name from filename (strip .md extension)
     - Call repo.Manager.AddCommand()
     - Print success message
   - Command logic for "add skill":
     - Validate path is a directory
     - Check for SKILL.md inside
     - Read and validate SKILL.md frontmatter
     - Verify folder name matches frontmatter name
     - Call repo.Manager.AddSkill()
     - Print success message

2. Add to root command in `cmd/root.go`

3. Error handling:
   - Path doesn't exist
   - Wrong type (file vs directory)
   - Not a valid resource (no/invalid frontmatter)
   - Resource name already exists (unless --force)
   - Permission errors
   - Name mismatch for skills (folder ≠ frontmatter name)

4. Add examples to help text for both subcommands

## Files to Create/Modify
- cmd/add.go
- cmd/root.go (register command)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Command runs: `ai-repo add command ./my-command.md`
- [ ] Command runs: `ai-repo add skill ./my-skill`
- [ ] Validates file vs folder correctly
- [ ] Validates frontmatter before adding
- [ ] For skills: validates folder name matches SKILL.md name field
- [ ] Copies resource to correct repo location
- [ ] Shows clear success/error messages
- [ ] Help text is clear: `ai-repo add --help`, `ai-repo add command --help`, `ai-repo add skill --help`
- [ ] --force flag works correctly
- [ ] Handles all error cases gracefully

## Dependencies
Depends on: ai-config-manager-vrs (repo manager must exist)

## Notes
Example usage:
```bash
# Add a command
ai-repo add command ~/.claude/commands/test.md
✓ Added command 'test' to repository

# Add a skill  
ai-repo add skill ~/my-skills/pdf-processing
✓ Added skill 'pdf-processing' (v1.0.0) to repository
```

This design allows for future expansion:
```bash
ai-repo add agent ./my-agent
ai-repo add tool ./my-tool
```
close_reason: Implemented 'ai-repo add' command with subcommands for command and skill. Added validation for file vs directory, .md extension, SKILL.md presence, and name matching. Implemented --force flag for overwrites. Added clear success messages with resource details. Tested successfully adding commands and skills. Help text works correctly.

     - Create installer instance

2. Add to root command in `cmd/root.go`

title: Remove verbose config file message
description:
## Problem
The shell autocomplete and all commands show this message:
```
Using config file: /home/hans/.ai-repo.yaml
```

This should ONLY appear when running `ai-repo config` subcommands (`config get`, `config set`), not for other commands like `list`, `add`, etc., and especially not during shell completion.

## Root Cause
```go
// cmd/root.go lines 77-79 in initConfig()
if err := viper.ReadInConfig(); err == nil {
    fmt.Fprintln(os.Stderr, "Using config file:", viper.ConfigFileUsed())
}
```

This prints on every command execution because `initConfig()` is called by cobra.OnInitialize().

## Solution

**Step 1: Remove verbose output from cmd/root.go**

In `cmd/root.go`, replace lines 77-79 with:
```go
viper.ReadInConfig() // read in config file if available
```

**Step 2: Add message to config subcommands in cmd/config.go**

Add the config file path output at the START of both `configGet()` and `configSet()` functions:

In `configGet()` function (after line 66, before line 68):
```go
fmt.Fprintf(os.Stderr, "Using config file: %s\n", viper.ConfigFileUsed())
```

In `configSet()` function (after line 91, before line 94):
```go
fmt.Fprintf(os.Stderr, "Using config file: %s\n", viper.ConfigFileUsed())
```

Note: You'll need to add `"github.com/spf13/viper"` to the imports in config.go.

## Files to Modify
- `cmd/root.go` - Remove the fmt.Fprintln from initConfig() (line 78)
- `cmd/config.go` - Add viper import and message to configGet() and configSet()

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `ai-repo list` - NO output about config file
- [ ] `ai-repo add --help` - NO output about config file  
- [ ] `ai-repo config get default-tool` - SHOWS "Using config file: ..."
- [ ] `ai-repo config set default-tool claude` - SHOWS "Using config file: ..."
- [ ] Shell completion - NO output
- [ ] Build succeeds with `make build`
- [ ] Tests pass with `make test`

## Testing
```bash
make build && make install
ai-repo list                              # Should NOT print "Using config file"
ai-repo add --help                        # Should NOT print "Using config file"
ai-repo config get default-tool           # SHOULD print "Using config file"
ai-repo config set default-tool opencode  # SHOULD print "Using config file"
source <(ai-repo completion bash)         # Should be silent
```
close_reason: Implementation verified complete. Removed verbose config message from initConfig() in cmd/root.go (already removed). Config file message now only appears in config get/set commands (already added). All tests pass, acceptance criteria verified.

title: Implement resource type definitions
description:
## Description
Define the core data structures for AI resources (commands and skills) based on actual formats from Claude Code and OpenCode.

## Background Research
- **Commands**: Single .md files with YAML frontmatter (like slash commands)
- **Skills**: Folders with SKILL.md + optional scripts/, references/, assets/ subdirs
- Reference: https://code.claude.com/docs/en/slash-commands
- Reference: https://agentskills.io/specification

## Instructions
1. Create `pkg/resource/types.go`:
   - Define `ResourceType` enum: `Command`, `Skill`
   - Define `Resource` struct with fields:
     - Name string
     - Type ResourceType
     - Description string (required)
     - Version string (optional, from metadata)
     - Author string (optional, from metadata)
     - License string (optional)
     - Path string (filesystem path)
     - Metadata map[string]string
   - Add YAML struct tags for all fields
   - Add validation methods: ValidateName(), ValidateDescription()

2. Create `pkg/resource/command.go`:
   - `type CommandResource struct` embedding Resource
   - Parse command frontmatter: description, agent, model, allowed-tools, etc.
   - Validation: single .md file, valid frontmatter

3. Create `pkg/resource/skill.go`:
   - `type SkillResource struct` embedding Resource
   - Parse SKILL.md frontmatter: name, description, license, compatibility, metadata
   - Validation: folder with SKILL.md, name matches folder, optional subdirs
   - Methods to check for scripts/, references/, assets/

4. Create `pkg/resource/metadata.go`:
   - Functions to read/parse frontmatter from .md files
   - ValidateName(): 1-64 chars, lowercase alphanumeric + hyphens, no leading/trailing/consecutive hyphens
   - ValidateDescription(): 1-1024 chars for skills, flexible for commands

5. Add tests in `pkg/resource/*_test.go`

## Files to Create/Modify
- pkg/resource/types.go
- pkg/resource/command.go
- pkg/resource/skill.go  
- pkg/resource/metadata.go
- pkg/resource/types_test.go
- pkg/resource/command_test.go
- pkg/resource/skill_test.go
- pkg/resource/testdata/ (test fixtures)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Resource types defined for Command and Skill
- [ ] Command: validates single .md file with frontmatter
- [ ] Skill: validates folder with SKILL.md
- [ ] Name validation: matches agentskills.io spec (lowercase alphanumeric + hyphens)
- [ ] Description validation: 1-1024 chars for skills
- [ ] YAML frontmatter parsing works
- [ ] Tests pass: `go test ./pkg/resource/...`
- [ ] Example fixtures demonstrate both formats

## Notes
Command example frontmatter:
```yaml
---
description: Run tests with coverage
agent: build
model: anthropic/claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022
---
```

Skill example frontmatter:
```yaml
---
name: pdf-processing
description: Extract text and tables from PDF files
license: Apache-2.0
metadata:
  author: example-org
  version: "1.0"
---
```
close_reason: Implemented resource type definitions with Command and Skill types. Created types.go with Resource struct, validation methods, and ResourceType enum. Implemented command.go and skill.go with loading/validation/writing functions. Created metadata.go with YAML frontmatter parsing. Added comprehensive tests with fixtures. All tests pass (18 tests total), builds successfully, no vet errors.

title: Setup GitHub Actions and Release Process
description:
## Description
Setup GitHub Actions workflows and automated release process similar to dtctl, using GoReleaser for multi-platform builds and releases.

## Research Summary (from dtctl)

**dtctl** uses:
- **GoReleaser** for automated releases with multi-platform binaries
- **GitHub Actions** for CI/CD
- Two main workflows:
  - `build.yml` - Runs on every push/PR, builds for all platforms
  - `release.yml` - Triggered on git tags (v*), uses GoReleaser

**Key Features:**
- Cross-platform builds: Linux, macOS, Windows (amd64, arm64)
- Version injection via ldflags
- Checksums and archives (tar.gz/zip)
- Automated changelog generation
- GitHub Releases integration

## Instructions

### 1. Create `.goreleaser.yaml`

Based on dtctl's config, create a GoReleaser configuration:

```yaml
version: 2

project_name: ai-repo

before:
  hooks:
    - go mod tidy

builds:
  - env:
      - CGO_ENABLED=0
    goos:
      - linux
      - darwin
      - windows
    goarch:
      - amd64
      - arm64
    ldflags:
      - -s -w
      - -X github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/pkg/version.Version={{.Version}}
      - -X github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/pkg/version.GitCommit={{.ShortCommit}}
      - -X github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/pkg/version.BuildDate={{.Date}}

archives:
  - format: tar.gz
    name_template: >-
      {{ .ProjectName }}_{{ .Version }}_{{ .Os }}_{{ .Arch }}
    format_overrides:
      - goos: windows
        format: zip

checksum:
  name_template: 'checksums.txt'

snapshot:
  version_template: "{{ incpatch .Version }}-next"

changelog:
  sort: asc
  filters:
    exclude:
      - '^docs:'
      - '^test:'
      - '^ci:'
      - Merge pull request
      - Merge branch
```

**Note**: Update `YOUR_USERNAME` to actual GitHub username

### 2. Create `.github/workflows/build.yml`

Create CI workflow that runs on every push/PR:

```yaml
name: Build

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  test:
    name: Test
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.25'

      - name: Run tests
        run: go test ./...

      - name: Run vet
        run: go vet ./...

  build:
    name: Build Binaries
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: test
    strategy:
      matrix:
        include:
          - goos: linux
            goarch: amd64
          - goos: linux
            goarch: arm64
          - goos: darwin
            goarch: amd64
          - goos: darwin
            goarch: arm64
          - goos: windows
            goarch: amd64
    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0

      - name: Set up Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.25'

      - name: Get version info
        id: version
        run: |
          VERSION=$(git describe --tags --always --dirty 2>/dev/null || echo "dev")
          COMMIT=$(git rev-parse --short HEAD 2>/dev/null || echo "unknown")
          DATE=$(date -u +"%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ")
          echo "version=$VERSION" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "commit=$COMMIT" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "date=$DATE" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT

      - name: Build binary
        env:
          GOOS: ${{ matrix.goos }}
          GOARCH: ${{ matrix.goarch }}
          CGO_ENABLED: 0
        run: |
          BINARY_NAME="ai-repo-${{ matrix.goos }}-${{ matrix.goarch }}"
          if [ "${{ matrix.goos }}" = "windows" ]; then
            BINARY_NAME="${BINARY_NAME}.exe"
          fi
          
          go build \
            -ldflags "-s -w -X github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/pkg/version.Version=${{ steps.version.outputs.version }} -X github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/pkg/version.GitCommit=${{ steps.version.outputs.commit }} -X github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/pkg/version.BuildDate=${{ steps.version.outputs.date }}" \
            -o "bin/${BINARY_NAME}" \
            .

      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
        with:
          name: ai-repo-${{ matrix.goos }}-${{ matrix.goarch }}
          path: bin/*
          if-no-files-found: error
          retention-days: 30
```

### 3. Create `.github/workflows/release.yml`

Create release workflow triggered by version tags:

```yaml
name: Release

on:
  push:
    tags:
      - 'v*'

permissions:
  contents: write

jobs:
  release:
    name: Release
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0

      - name: Set up Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.25'

      - name: Run GoReleaser
        uses: goreleaser/goreleaser-action@v6
        with:
          version: latest
          args: release --clean
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
```

### 4. Create `.github/workflows/lint.yml` (Optional but recommended)

```yaml
name: Lint

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  golangci:
    name: Lint
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.25'

      - name: golangci-lint
        uses: golangci/golangci-lint-action@v6
        with:
          version: latest
```

### 5. Update `.gitignore`

Add build artifacts:

```
# Binaries
bin/
dist/
ai-repo
*.exe

# GoReleaser
.goreleaser.dist.yml
```

### 6. Update README.md

Add installation section:

```markdown
## Installation

### Download Binary

Download the latest release for your platform:

**Linux (amd64)**:
```bash
curl -L https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/releases/latest/download/ai-repo_VERSION_linux_amd64.tar.gz | tar xz
sudo mv ai-repo /usr/local/bin/
```

**macOS (Apple Silicon)**:
```bash
curl -L https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/releases/latest/download/ai-repo_VERSION_darwin_arm64.tar.gz | tar xz
sudo mv ai-repo /usr/local/bin/
```

**Windows (PowerShell)**:
```powershell
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/releases/latest/download/ai-repo_VERSION_windows_amd64.zip" -OutFile "ai-repo.zip"
Expand-Archive -Path "ai-repo.zip" -DestinationPath "."
```

Or visit the [Releases page](https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager/releases) to download manually.

### From Source

```bash
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/ai-config-manager.git
cd ai-config-manager
make build
make install
```
```

### 7. Create Release Documentation

Create `docs/RELEASE.md`:

```markdown
# Release Process

## Creating a New Release

1. **Update version** in code if needed
2. **Commit all changes**
3. **Create and push tag**:
   ```bash
   git tag -a v0.1.0 -m "Release v0.1.0"
   git push origin v0.1.0
   ```
4. **GitHub Actions automatically**:
   - Builds binaries for all platforms
   - Creates GitHub Release
   - Uploads binaries and checksums
   - Generates changelog

title: Implement repository manager
description:
## Description
Build the repository manager that handles the ~/.ai-config/repo/ directory structure for commands (files) and skills (folders).

## Instructions
1. Create `pkg/repo/manager.go`:
   - `type Manager struct` with repo path
   - `NewManager()` - initializes with ~/.ai-config/repo/ (use adrg/xdg)
   - `Init()` - creates repo directories if not exist
   - `AddCommand(sourcePath string) error` - copies .md file to repo/commands/
   - `AddSkill(sourcePath string) error` - copies skill folder to repo/skills/
   - `List(resourceType *ResourceType) ([]Resource, error)` - lists resources (filter by type if provided)
   - `Get(name string, resourceType ResourceType) (*Resource, error)` - gets specific resource
   - `Remove(name string, resourceType ResourceType) error` - removes resource from repo
   - `GetPath(name string, resourceType ResourceType) string` - returns full path to resource

2. Repository structure:
   ```
   ~/.ai-config/repo/
     commands/
       my-command.md          # Command files stored flat
       another-command.md
     skills/
       skill-name/            # Skill folders
         SKILL.md
         scripts/
         references/
       another-skill/
         SKILL.md
   ```

3. AddCommand logic:
   - Validate source is a single .md file
   - Parse and validate frontmatter
   - Extract name from filename (without .md)
   - Copy to repo/commands/<name>.md
   - Validate name doesn't conflict

4. AddSkill logic:
   - Validate source is a directory with SKILL.md
   - Parse and validate SKILL.md frontmatter
   - Verify name in frontmatter matches folder name
   - Copy entire folder to repo/skills/<name>/
   - Validate name doesn't conflict

5. Handle edge cases:
   - Repo doesn't exist (auto-create)
   - Resource name conflicts (error)
   - Invalid resource structure (error)
   - Missing metadata/frontmatter (error)

6. Add tests in `pkg/repo/manager_test.go`

## Files to Create/Modify
- pkg/repo/manager.go
- pkg/repo/manager_test.go

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Manager initializes repo directory structure
- [ ] Can add commands (single .md files) to repo/commands/
- [ ] Can add skills (folders) to repo/skills/
- [ ] Can list all resources or filter by type
- [ ] Can get specific resource by name and type
- [ ] Can remove resource from repo
- [ ] Handles errors gracefully
- [ ] Tests pass: `go test ./pkg/repo/...`
- [ ] Uses XDG paths correctly (~/.ai-config/repo/)

## Dependencies
Depends on: ai-config-manager-8ay (resource types must be defined first)

## Notes
- Commands are stored as flat files in commands/
- Skills are stored as directories in skills/
- Use filepath.Join for cross-platform path handling
- Consider using os.CopyFS or io.Copy for file/folder copies
- Validate resources before adding to repo

Implemented Init, AddCommand, AddSkill, List, Get, Remove, and GetPath methods. Added recursive directory copying for skills with subdirectories. Handles conflicts and validates resources. All 11 tests pass. Builds and vets successfully.

title: Add --version flag to show version
description:
## Description
Add a `--version` flag to the ai-repo CLI that displays the current version number.

## Instructions

1. **Create version package** (`pkg/version/version.go`):
   - Define `Version` constant (e.g., "0.1.0" or "dev")
   - Define `BuildDate` variable (injected at build time)
   - Define `GitCommit` variable (injected at build time)
   - Add `GetVersion()` function that returns formatted version string

2. **Update root command** (`cmd/root.go`):
   - Add `--version` flag to root command
   - When flag is used, print version and exit
   - Format: `ai-repo version X.Y.Z (commit: abc123, built: 2026-01-18)`

3. **Update Makefile**:
   - Add version injection during build using `-ldflags`
   - Example: `-ldflags "-X pkg/version.Version=0.1.0 -X pkg/version.GitCommit=$(git rev-parse --short HEAD) -X pkg/version.BuildDate=$(date -u +%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ)"`
   - Update `build` target to inject version info

4. **Set initial version**:
   - Use semantic versioning (e.g., "0.1.0" for initial release)
   - Document versioning strategy in README

## Files to Create
- pkg/version/version.go

## Files to Modify
- cmd/root.go (add --version flag)
- Makefile (add ldflags for version injection)
- README.md (document version command)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `ai-repo --version` displays version number
- [ ] Version shows git commit hash when available
- [ ] Version shows build date when available
- [ ] Makefile injects version info during build
- [ ] Binary built with `make build` shows correct version
- [ ] Help text mentions --version flag

## Example Output
```
$ ai-repo --version
ai-repo version 0.1.0 (commit: a1b2c3d, built: 2026-01-18T19:30:00Z)

$ ./ai-repo --version  # without make build
ai-repo version dev
```

## Notes
- Use `-ldflags` at build time to inject git commit and build date
- Default to "dev" when not built with version injection
close_reason: Implemented --version flag: Created pkg/version/version.go with Version/GitCommit/BuildDate variables and GetVersion() function, updated cmd/root.go to add -v/--version flags, updated Makefile to inject version info via ldflags during build (version 0.1.0), updated README with version command examples. Tests pass. Binary shows 'dev' when built without make, and full version with commit and date when built with make.
